title: 105_hr1326
content: The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes an amendment to Title 31. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" includes a new section in Title 31, United States Code, allowing for continuing appropriations if regular appropriation bills are not passed before the fiscal year begins. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" allows for continuing appropriations at a rate of operations not exceeding ninety-five percent of the previous fiscal year's funding for projects or activities. These appropriations are available from the beginning of the fiscal year. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" allows for continuing appropriations for projects or activities during a lapse in appropriations, subject to terms and conditions from the previous fiscal year. The "Government Shutdown Prevention Act" allows for continuing appropriations for projects or activities during a lapse in appropriations, subject to terms and conditions from the previous fiscal year. Expenditures for a project or activity in a fiscal year must be charged to the appropriate appropriation when a regular appropriation bill becomes law. This section does not apply if another law already provides funding or authority for the project or activity. The term 'regular appropriation bill' refers to annual bills that provide funding or authority for various projects and activities in categories such as agriculture, rural development, defense, and government operations in the District of Columbia. The curr_chunk lists various activities chargeable against District revenues, including departments like Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Housing and Urban Development, Energy and Water Development, Foreign Assistance, Interior, Military Construction, Transportation, Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and the legislative branch. The analysis of chapter 13 of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new item after section 1310. The amendments made by this Act, titled "Continuing appropriations," do not affect Government obligations mandated by other laws, including Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. These amendments will apply to fiscal years starting from 1998.
